results.title: The Week in pictures. Issue no. 294
results.brief_description: Newsreel items include: The happenings and description of charm schools; renowned variety stars - The Voltaires; pupils at the Royal Navy Gunnery School get cracking under realistic training conditions; the World’s largest road vehicle, The Antar, on display before being shipped to the Middle east; Joe Davis, snooker champion shows of his skilled wares at the table.

results.title: The Wedding party [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Oudine Productions, Brian De Palma, Wilfred Leach and Cynthia Munroe
results.brief_description: De Palma’s early black comedy tells the tale of Charlie and Jospehine, two college students who have decided to marry. But as the wedding day approaches the differences between the groom and the bride’s social worlds cause Charlie to rethink his tying of the knot. Set in the cloistered, snobbish world of New York “aristocracy”, “The Wedding Party” is a prankish send-up of family, wealth and matrimonial rites. Before developing the Hitchcock-influenced baroque horror films that were to make his reputation, De Palma was a comedy writer, activist and performer closely allied to the counter-culture and anti-Vietnam War movement. “The Wedding Party” makes clear its origins in the radical student subculture of the 1960s, but for a film based on a script which is dangerously chaotic and improvisary, De Palma’s masterful direction results in a film which is both coherent and elegant. Jill Clayburgh stars as the dizzy spoilt rich-brat Josephine and it features an early film performance by Robert de Niro as Charlie’s best friend, Cecil. With Jennifer Salt, Charles Pfluger.

results.title: The Web
results.creator_credit: Eco Productions, Film Victoria, Australian Children's Television Foundation, Australian Film Commission, New South Wales Film and Television Office, ABC-TV (Australia), Fiona Eagger, Lucinda Clutterbuck, Sarah Watt and Elisa Argenzio
results.brief_description: Narrated by Ruth Cracknell and superbly animated, thirteen short segments focus on the survival of endangered creatures in their fragile habitats. The emphasis is on highlighting the plight of the animals and to foster greater community respect. Preservation of wildlife and their habitats are crucial environmental issues, and this program of short films promotes this message simply and persuasively. The Panda, Wolf, Bandicoot, Cheetah, Shark, Rhinoceros, Falcon, Rattlesnake, Spider, Seal, Gorilla, Frog and Homo Sapiens are the animals featured. Suitable for Upper Primary students and for lovers of quality animation and wildlife.

results.title: The Weather map
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Malcolm Otton and Christopher Cordeaux
results.brief_description: Explains how to interpret a weather map and how the Bureau produces it daily from the information collected by stations throughout Australia. Aimed at upper primary-, lower high school-aged students.

results.title: The Weather
results.brief_description: The circulation of the air about the earth’s surface, the progress of a wave cyclone with detailed consideration of the cold and the warm front, and the instruments used in weather observation, are studied in this film.

results.title: The Weakest link
results.creator_credit: British Foundation Pictures and Ronald Haines
results.brief_description: A very interesting film showing a community in England hand forging and forming of chain links. Both women and men working with primitive machines using methods that are timeless.

results.title: The Ways of water
results.brief_description: A study of water movement, currents, tides and waves and its application in irrigation and canal control. Filmed at the Hydraulic Research Station, Wallingford, England.

results.title: The Wayne manifesto: this guy Dellafield
results.creator_credit: Artist Services, Film Queensland, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Alan Hardy and Paul Moloney
results.brief_description: In ‘This guy Dellafield’, Wayne’s first day at school does not look like it’s going to be a good one, especially when he has school bullies and a tyrannical teacher to deal with. In the second episode ‘A slave to fashion’, Wayne is convinced that he hasn’t made any new friends at school; apart from Rosie, the young girl next door. In an effort to rectify the situation, Wayne blows his chance as making it as a triangle player in Squaka’s band. Cast includes Jeffrey Walker (Wayne), Jah’shua McAvoy, Tracey-Louise Smith and Brooke Harman.

results.title: The Wayne manifesto: the alien
results.creator_credit: Artist Services, Film Queensland, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Alan Hardy and Paul Moloney
results.brief_description: In “A Wayne in a manger”, Wayne, his family, and his father’s toilet collection have just moved to a real dump of a house. To make matters worse they have arrived well ahead of their furniture, and just in time for Christmas. It looks like it’s going to be the worst Christmas on record. In “The Alien”, after surviving puberty and his hellish neighbours, Wayne is convinced he’s an alien, and he’s not the only one that thinks so. He enlists the help of his friends Squaka and Violet and their alien detector to get to the truth of the matter. Cast includes Jeffrey Walker (Wayne), Jah’shua McAvoy, Tracey-Louise Smith and Brooke Harman.
